column15: What's your favorite thing about meeting with readers?
column16: What is the weirdest question you've ever gotten from a reader?
column17: What are you most looking forward to about the Collingswood Book Festival? (if you've been here before)

column4: Maria E. Andreu is the author of Love in English (Balzer + Bray, 2021), about a sixteen-year-old who has just moved to the United States and can barely understand what's going on around her. The book was an Indie Next Pick and Junior Library Guild Gold Standard Selection. Andreu's next book, as-yet untitled, is scheduled for release in 2022. Her work has appeared in Literary Hub, Teen Vogue, Newsweek, The Washington Post, NJ.com, and the Newark Star Ledger. Her debut young adult novel, The Secret Side of Empty, was a Junior Library Guild Selection, a National Indie Excellence Book Award winner, and an International Latino Book Awards Finalist. It was described as "a compelling and timely story" by Horn Book Reviews and “captivating” by School Library Journal. Maria is Latinx and Argentinian-American and currently lives in New Jersey just outside New York City. Her work has been informed by her experiences as a formerly undocumented, non-native English speaker and immigrant to the U.S. She is the queen of rooting for the happy ending, also queen of not being sure about it.
column5: Sixteen-year-old Ana has just moved to the U.S. for her Junior year of high school. She’s a poet and a lover of language except that now, she can barely understand what’s going on around her. It’s a story that is simultaneously charming and romantic, while articulating a deeper story about what it means to become “American”.
column6:
Love in English, 978-0062996510
The Secret Side of Empty, 978-0062996510
column15: Hearing about them, what they're reading, and what they love about stories!
column16: I don't know if it's weird, but I have been asked "How rich are you?" Which is sweet and funny.
column17: I love going back to the festival year after year because it's such a warm, inviting community.

column4: Darlene Beck Jacobson is a former teacher and speech therapist who has loved writing since she was a girl. She is also a lover of history and can often be found mining dusty closets and drawers in search of skeletons from her past. She enjoys adding these bits of her ancestry to stories such as the middle grade historical novel Wheels of Change (Creston 2014), which was chosen as a 2015 Notable Social-Studies Trade Book by the Children’s Book Council (CBC), a 2015 Mighty Girl Pick, and 2015 Honorable Mention for The Grateful American Book Prize. Her middle grade novel-in-verse Wishes, Dares, And How To Stand Up To A Bully (Creston 2020) was named a Notable Verse Novel for 2021 by the CBC. Darlene lives and writes her stories in New Jersey with her family and a house full of dust bunnies. She's caught many fish, but never asked one to grant her a wish. She's a firm believer in wishes coming true, so she tries to be careful what she wishes for. Her blog features recipes, activities, crafts, articles on nature, book reviews, and interviews with children's book authors and illustrators.
column5: Eleven year old Jack misses his Dad who is MIA in Vietnam. It's been months since he and his family had word of his whereabouts. The last thing Jack wants to do is spend summer with his grandparents. Mom believes it will be good for them all -- Jack, his sister Katy, Mom, Gran and Pops -- to be together while they wait for word about Dad. Keeping busy will keep them out of trouble and help them think of other things. Jack expects the worst summer of his life. The first summer without. Without Dad, without friends, without his room and all the things that remind him of Dad. When Jack meets a girl named Jill -- a girl with a brother who makes trouble for both of them -- things they believe are turned upside down. Welcome to a summer of fishing, camping, bullies, and a fish who grants wishes. A fish that could be the answer to Jack's problem. But when Jill makes wishes of her own, things don't turn out the way they expected. Every wish has a consequence. Will the fish grant Jack's biggest wish? Will Jack be brave enough to ask?
column6: WISHES, DARES, AND HOW TO STAND UP TO A BULLY (Creston 2020)  ISBN: 978-1-939547-62-0
column15: Being able to talk face to face with readers about their favorite books and authors and feel the excitement as they share their enthusiasm.
column17:
Being outside at my favorite venue is always something to look forward to. 

Reconnecting with fellow authors is a highlight. This is my favorite book festival.

column4: Until Hollywood calls, Charlotte Bennardo is working on her MFA/Professional Writer degree and working on several novels. She writes science fiction, fantasy, contemporary, and horror for middle grade up to adult. Besides her Evolution Revolution trilogy, she has co-authored three young adult novels: Blonde OPS, Sirenz, and Sirenz Back in Fashion. Her short stories have appeared in two anthologies, Beware the Little White Rabbit and Scare Me to Sleep. She has written numerous newspaper, magazine, ezine, and blog posts on both non-fiction and fiction subjects. She has given workshops and presentations on various aspects of writing and publishing at conferences, book festivals, libraries, schools, and other book events. She is a member of the Society of Children's Book Writers and Illustrators, the Authors Guild, the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America, and the Kidlit Authors Club. While she waits for a new squirrel to move into her backyard, she's working on a young adult novel about a blacksmith time traveling from King Arthur's court to present day England.
column5: The Evolution Revolution Trilogy (Simple Machines, Simple Plans, Simple Lessons) follows the adventure of a gray squirrel named Jack, who makes friends with Collin, a young boy. Jack becomes distressed when construction machines show up, planning to cut down his woods and tree. When Collin shows Jack how to use simple machines like the wheel, Jack begins a plan to use what Collin teaches him and gather all the woodland animals to fight back -- and stop the machines. He teaches them what he's learned. When the animals begin winning the battle, scientists try to catch Jack and some of his friends whom Jack has to rescue. Hiding in Collin's house, Jack and Collin figure out a way to communicate -- until Jack has to go into hiding. It's soon a battle and only one of them is going to win; if the scientists win, they will capture Jack and study him, but if Jack and the animals win, they can teach what they've learned to other animals who can then protect their homes. Based on the third-grade science curriculum teaching simple machines, this adventure trilogy presents STEM principles in an adventurous, fun, and fast paced story with irresistible animal characters.
column15: I love talking books! What they like to read, what I like to read, how to write one, what I'd like to see, what do they want me to write?
column16: How come you wrote about the devil? (My book Sirenz is about the Greek god of the Underworld, Hades, and while he's devilishly handsome and charming, he's not the devil.)
column17: People! This is my favorite festival because the community really comes out and supports all authors.

column4: Jeff Campbell has published two previous young adult books about animals: Daisy to the Rescue (a 2015 IPPY gold medal winner), about animals saving human lives and the science of animal intelligence; and Last of the Giants (a 2016 Junior Library Guild selection), about conservation and our current extinction crisis. For twelve years, Jeff was an award-winning travel writer for Lonely Planet, and he’s also a book editor and creative writing teacher.
column5: With modern bioengineering, science fiction’s “what if?” has become the scientist’s “why not?” Today, we have the tools to remake animals in almost any way we want, and genetic engineering is being used to help solve a range of urgent problems related to climate change, species extinctions, conservation, disease, human health, and in the food industry. But as science fiction likes to warn us, altering animals isn’t without dangers, and it raises profound ethical questions. Glowing Bunnies!? explores how genetic engineering is currently reshaping animals and our world and asks that all-important question: Given what we can do, what should we do?
column6: Glowing Bunnies!?: Why We're Making Hybrids, Chimeras, and Clones (May 2022; ISBN (pb): 978-1-5415-9930-7)
column15: I love talking about our amazing world, particularly the incredible animals we share it with, and finding out what excites readers. I always hope to share one fact someone didn't know before, as well as to imagine all the possibilities the future holds.
column16: All questions are good questions. I never think any are weird. In fact, animal bioengineering, the topic of Glowing Bunnies, is itself so bizarre that any question you can think of is reasonable.

column4: J.Donnini is a children's book author, musician, professional daydreamer and a mother, which she considers her most important job. She spent many years studying and writing music and lyrics but transitioned to strictly writing for children when her son was born in 2007. Musical and lyrical qualities can always be found in her picture books. J's stories focus on empathy, diversity and social emotional issues as well as love and respect for each other and this beautiful planet that we all share. She wants to not only entertain, but empower young readers and honor their curiosity and wonder. J's published works include Ruby Lee, Echoes, Fireflies, The Spirit Bunnies, Patches and the Spirit Bunnies, Rock and the Fly, and her latest, This Will Pass, published by Bushel & Peck books. She has been a featured author at various reading events, book festivals, and stores such as Barnes & Noble. She believes in the pure joy of imagination and creativity.
column5:
A charming reminder for kids that even the worst things don't last forever. 

"Unlike many picture books that seek to comfort young audiences by assuring them that their apprehensions are unfounded, Donnini's quiet prose shows readers that worry is a feeling as valid as any other . . . the world is an increasingly worrisome place, and books like this one, that offer simple acknowledgement of this fact, are just as essential as those that offer elaborate escape. Timely assurance of the impermanence of life's difficulties." -- Kirkus Reviews

It's time for little Crue's first big adventure with his Great Uncle Ollie, but he can't help but worry: What if the boat breaks? Or an octopus swallows them in one gulp? Or a family of whales takes over the boat?

It seems the worries will follow him around forever until Great Uncle Ollie squeezes his hand and shares his secret mantra: Be calm, it will pass. Through storms . . . Be calm, it will pass . . . passing sharks . . . Be calm, it will pass . . . even through a pirate attack . . . Be calm, it will pass . . . Great Uncle Ollie's mantra keeps Crue afloat until it's time for a solo journey of his own.

For kids who worry or stress over life's troubles, This Will Pass is a welcome lesson in mindful patience.

column4: Award-winning author Donna Gephart's middle grade novels include: Abby, Tried and True, The Paris Project, Lily and Dunkin, How to Survive Middle School, and Death by Toilet Paper. Her picture book -- Go Be Wonderful -- celebrates milestones in a young child's life and being perfectly imperfect. Donna is a popular speaker at schools, conferences and book festivals. She loves to hike, cook vegan food and, of course, read!
column5: When poet Abby Braverman’s best friend, Cat, moves to Israel, she’s sure it’s the worst thing that could happen. But then her older brother, Paul, is diagnosed with testicular cancer, and life upends again. Now it’s up to Abby to find a way to navigate seventh grade without her best friend, help keep her brother’s spirits up during difficult treatments, and figure out her surprising new feelings for the charming boy who moved in next door. Luckily, Abby has two supportive moms, a warm, loving extended Jewish family and her beloved turtle, Fudge, as she learns that strength can come from a place of quiet determination and deep love.
column6:
Abby, Tried and True, April 5, 2022, 978-1534440906
Go Be Wonderful, March 30, 2021, ‎ 978-0823445110
The Paris Project, October 6, 2020, 978-1534440876
Lily and Dunkin, May 1, 2018, 978-0553536775
column15: Listening to them. Learning what's important to them. Hearing about their favorite books.
column16: "What do you have against hamsters?" -- in reference to a scene from HOW TO SURVIVE MIDDLE SCHOOL "Nothing! I love animals!"
column17: Meeting with young readers who are as excited and enthusiastic about books as I am!

column4: Kwame Ivery was born in Bronx, New York and raised in East Orange, New Jersey. He received a BA in psychology from Princeton University and an MFA in Dramatic Writing from New York University's Tisch School Of The Arts. He’s had a screenplay optioned by Hollywood storyboard artist Karl Shefelman (The Silence of the Lambs, American Gangster, etc.) His debut novel, The Problem with the Other Side, was released by Soho Teen on September 7, 2021, and explores the effects of a racially-charged student government campaign on the candidates' friends and families. He’s a proud high school English teacher with 100-plus teenage students who, on a daily basis, teach him just as many things as he teaches them. He loves lasagna and hates musicals; he thinks contrasts are underrated and symmetry overrated.
column5: Told in two voices, the budding romance between tenth-graders Uly Gates and Sallie Walls is tested when their sisters run against each other in a racially-charged, increasingly combative campaign for student-body president.
column6:
THE PROBLEM WITH THE OTHER SIDE
--Publication Date = 9/7/21
--ISBN = 978-1641292054
column15: I enjoy answering readers' questions, listening to their comments/observations, and learning about their backgrounds.
column16: What was it like doing the artwork for your book's cover?

column4: Jeffry W. Johnston's first published novel, Fragments, was an Edgar award nominee for Best Young Adult Mystery. Both Fragments and The Truth, his second novel, were Quick Picks for Reluctant Young Adult Readers by the Young Adult Library Services Association (YALSA). Following, his latest novel, was a Junior Library Gold Standard Selection. Jeffry is also a member of the Kidlit Authors Club.
column5: Alden likes to follow people. He's not trying to be a creep; he wants to be an investigator someday, and it's good practice. But spying on people comes with risks, like when Alden sees popular Greg Matthes seemingly murder his girlfriend, Amy, in the bad part of town. But the facts aren't adding up, especially because Amy may be alive. Now Alden has to figure out what he could have seen ... and what secrets Greg is hiding.
column6:
FOLLOWING, published by Sourcebooks Fire 
ISBN-10: 1492664618
ISBN-13: 978-1492664611
column15: The things teen readers have to say always fascinates me.
column17: It's one of my favorite book festivals.

column4: Dianne K. Salerni is the author of middle grade and YA novels, including Eleanor, Alice, & the Roosevelt Ghosts, the Eighth Day series, The Caged Graves, and We Hear the Dead. Her latest book, Jadie in Five Dimensions, is a multi-dimensional adventure steeped in science and math. Dianne was a public school teacher for 25 years before leaving the profession to spend more time hanging around creepy cemeteries, attending ghost hunting classes, and climbing two-thousand-year-old pyramids in the name of book research.
column5: ELEANOR, ALICE, & THE ROOSEVELT GHOSTS is a mystery set in an alternate U.S. history where ghosts are real and categorized into 3 types: Friendly, Unaware, and Vengeful. Young Eleanor Roosevelt and her rambunctious cousin Alice (daughter of Teddy Roosevelt) match wits with a ghost that might have deceived authorities into believing it was harmless. A fun, mysterious romp through a supernatural New York with the Roosevelts! ~ Book Bustle JADIE IN FIVE DIMENSIONS is a multi-dimensional adventure steeped in geometry and physics. Former abandoned baby Jadie, now adopted into a loving family and serving as an agent for super-intelligent beings from the 4th dimension, discovers that her origin story is a lie and that her birth family has been manipulated by multi-dimensional forces for unknown purposes.A complex, engaging sci-fi adventure that offers a different perspective on our world, literally from a dimension beyond.~ School Library Journal
column6:
Eleanor, Alice, & the Roosevelt Ghosts, 2021 (in paperback), 978-0823449910

Jadie in Five Dimensions, 2021, 978-0823449095
column15: As a former teacher, I love interacting with young readers and talking about what they love to read.
column16: Readers sometimes grill me about the romantic futures of my middle grade characters -- that is, who do I "ship" with whom?
column17: I have missed interacting with young readers, parents, teachers, and librarians during the long duration of the pandemic. I can't wait to talk to people again!

column4: Eric Smith is a literary agent and Young Adult author living in Philadelphia. He's worked on New York Times bestselling and award-winning books. His recent novels include Don't Read the Comments, You Can Go Your Own Way, and Jagged Little Pill: The Novel. Jagged Little Pill— written with Alanis Morrisette, Diablo Cody, and Glenn Ballard—is an adaptation of the award-winning musical. You Can Go Your Own Way is a YA rom-com set in a failing pinball arcade in Philadelphia.
column5: Jagged Little Pill: The Novel - Written with Alanis Morrisette, Diablo Cody, and Glenn Ballard, it's an adaptation of the award-winning musical. You Can Go Your Own Way - a YA rom-com set in a failing pinball arcade in Philadelphia. Don't Read the Comments - a YA novel half set in a video game world, that addresses sexism and racism in online communities.
column6:
Jagged Little Pill: The Novel (Abrams, April 2022)
You Can Go Your Own Way (Inkyard Press, November 2021)
Don't Read the Comments (Inkyard Press, January 2020)
column12: Answering questions and chatting about their own writing goals.

column4: A Jersey girl by birth, Kate Szegda grew up in Highland Park and Point Pleasant Beach. She is a graduate of Georgian Court University. Now retired, Mrs. Szegda once taught middle school ELA and later worked in teacher education at the University of Delaware. Today she enjoys reading, writing, golf, and lunch with friends. Szegda's book Pharmacy Girl is a middle-grade historical novel about the 1918 Spanish influenza pandemic in New Jersey. Schools, restaurants, and even churches closed. One in four Americans were stricken, and an estimated 675,000 Americans died. There were no effective vaccines. No ventilators. No medicines to stop a virus. But Josie, whose school nemesis calls her Pharmacy Girl, steps up to help her family when the pandemic strikes home. Pharmacy Girl has won awards from the California Teachers' Association, National Federation of Press Women, and Delaware Press Association Award for Children’s Fiction, was a finalist for the 2020 American Book Fest Best Book Awards and 2021 Readers' Favorite International Book Awards, and won the 2019 Moonbeam Children’s Fiction Silver Medal for Pre-teen Historical/Cultural Fiction.
column5: Pharmacy Girl is middle-grade historical fiction about the 1918 Spanish influenza pandemic in New Jersey. Before COVID there was Spanish influenza. In 1918 there were masks. Schools, restaurants, and even churches closed. A nation at war curtailed the draft. One in four Americans stricken, and an estimated 675,000 Americans dead. All because of a deadly germ carried on a puff of air. But there were no effective vaccines. No ventilators. No medicines to stop a virus. And a war to win. Everyone likes Josie, except the spoiled and arrogant Billy Detwiler. He calls her Pharmacy Girl, but it is no compliment. As the hazy days of September 1918 drift into the deadly autumn of Spanish influenza, Josie’s everyday problems of school and friends, even the war effort at home, become insignificant when her mother comes down with the flu. But Josie is no slacker. She faces Billy in a class election, raises money for the Liberty Loan, and steps up to help her family when the pandemic strikes home. 2021-2022 California Teachers' Association pick for California Reads 2021 Readers' Favorite International Book Award Finalist, Children's Pre-teen Fiction 2020 National Federation of Press Women 2nd Place Award for Children’s Fiction 2020 Delaware Press Association Award for Children’s Fiction 2020 American Book Fest, Best Book Awards, Finalist, Children's Fiction 2019 Moonbeam Children’s Fiction Silver Medal for Pre-teen Historical/Cultural Fiction
column15: I love meeting readers, and I love the conversations we have about Spanish influenza. Many people did not know much about the Spanish influenza epidemic of 1918 until now; they often express their surprise at finding out about it. Other readers share their own family stories of Spanish influenza, and I am so glad we can make those connections.
column17: Main Street Collingswood is a delightful venue for a street fair. The last time I was at the Collingswood Book Festival it was the perfect October day. Fingers crossed for fair weather once again. And, of course, I can’t wait to talk with readers!

column4: Yvonne Ventresca is an award-winning author with an MFA in writing for children and young adults from Vermont Colle
